Title: N/A

reviewText: Overall I love the movie genre known as "blaxploitation". The style and mannerism and talk and over-the-top action is all uniquely urban 70's. This particular collection is a 4 movie/2 DVD set featuring some well-known blaxploitation actors of that era such as Jim Kelly and Fred Williamson. Since this is an official Warner Bros. release, we at least get subtitles and decent picture quality(most of these type of movies are released in public domain sets with lousy transfers).My two favorite movies in this collection are 'Black Belt Jones' and 'Black Samson'. 'Black Samson' features a real lion in a stripper bar and a crazy final rooftop battle sequence involving sofas and kitchen sinks(among other things). This movie also features eternal bad-guy William Smith, the actor who was so adept at playing villain roles during the 70's. In this movie he plays the 'bad ass' mobster who defies the older mob figure(who insist on a gentler way of doing things) and decides to go after Black Samson himself.'Black Belt Jones' stars Jim Kelly(known as the 'Black Bruce Lee'). The story is about some goofy mob characters who want to take over a run-down building with a karate studio. This movie also features Scatman Crothers, the talented musician/actor/entertainer who appeared in a multitude of movie and TV roles dating back to the 1950's. One of the things I like about this movie is that it was filmed in the actual ghetto locations in Los Angeles back in the day, so you get kind of a time-capsule of that era.'Hot Potato' was overly silly/annoying and I could barely get through half of the movie. 'Three The Hard Way' was decent with an alright story that felt a bit scattered. The three main actors is what saves the movie. Overall this collection gives a good representation or taste of the black action/urban movies of that era.

reviewText: Jim Kelly became a household name in my circle after he exploded on the scene in Enter The Dragon. His martial arts prowess lead him to several more martial arts starring roles including Black Belt Jones and Three The Hard Way. This is a great film. These were three of the black action legends together in a movie that have them fighting to save the black race. It was easy enough for us to believe that if anyone could do it, it would be these three. In Black Belt Jones Kelly is joined by the lovely Gloria Henry. She actually took the spotlight whenever they were together. Gloria was a better actor. However no one could top Kelly once the fighting began. A good film. Kicks butt!

reviewText: So glad to add legit, non-bootleg versions of "Black Belt Jones" & "Three The Hard Way" - two of the pantheons of Blaxploitation Cinema - to my DVD collection.  I saw "Hot Potato" over 20 years ago and thought it was dumb.  I didn't know that "Hot Potato" was a sequel of sorts to "Black Belt Jones" - I'll bear that in mind when I watch that one again. I had never seen "Black Samson" before and, after checking it out, I thought it was easily forgettable.  I was expecting the hero of that flick to unleash his pet lion on the mobsters in the final action sequence but, alas, no luck.Picture looks great on my 55 inch Sony HDTV.  I expected to see tons of grain in the picture given the fact that these are obscure 1970's titles, but the picture quality on all 4 films is FANTASTIC!  The sound is mono - wish they did a stereo mix of these flicks so the memorable theme from "Black Belt Jones" and those classic songs from "Three The Hard Way" would really come alive - but that's a minor complaint.Hopefully WB will do a sequel to this 4 film collection soon and release some other Blaxploitation titles - most notably the sequel to Cleopatra Jones and others from the pre-1986 MGM library including "Cool Breeze", "Melinda", and "Hit Man" (yeah, those are "on DVD" already, but they're BOOTLEGS copied from crappy VHS tapes!).  All in all, I will gladly spend my MLK weekend soaking up all the Jim Kelly action I can muster!

reviewText: I purchased this Warner Bros. 4-pack primarily for "Black Belt Jones", the film that reunites actor Jim Kelly and director Robert Clouse from Bruce Lee's classic "Enter the Dragon".  The fact that this features 3 other Blaxploitation films, 2 of which star Kelly, made purchase a no-brainer for me.  Further investigation found all 4 films remastered, in widescreen, and with optional French or English subtitles!  Price weren't too shabby neither!BLACK BELT JONESJim Kelly plays the title character who must be some kind of secret agent or something cuz the cops want his help in nabbing some mobsters but the only job we ever see this cat do is teach some ladies techniques on the trampoline.  He turns down the cops' request but gets involved anyway when these same mobsters realize that the Karate school he trained at is located smack in the middle of the spot they want to procure for the city's new civic center.  This school is owned & operated by Papa Byrd (the one-and-only Scatman Crothers, "The Shining") whose irresponsible gambling debt the mob plans to exploit through local hustler Pinky (Malik Carter, "Cobra", who looks like he was retro-cloned from Bernie Mac and the guy who played Grady on "Sanford & Son") and his band of Bogarts.  Pinky's thugs find out that Byrd doesn't own the school but signed it over to someone named Sydney (Gloria Hendry, "Freaky Deaky").While not as good as I remember it's still silly and fun and while the flick has a fair amount of fighting, most of it's not that good.  Though there are some moments.  I would almost bump it up a star just for the presence of Scatman Crothers.  I, like most people, can't help but like the dude and here he even gets to fight a little.  Otherwise the large cast is mostly made up of pupils and thugs.  The student Quincy is played by Eric Laneuville who would later play Chuck Norris's kickboxing son in "A Force of One".  The thug with the Jamaican hat is played by Donnie Williams, who I've seen in tiny fighting roles throughout the '70s & '80s, including some Hong Kong films and is also in "A Force of One", where neither he nor Laneuville do very well against Bill "Superfoot" Wallace.All-in-all, I can't decide between a 2.5 or a 3.  Kelly and Clouse had the resources and talent to come up with something a lot better so it's hard to keep one's expectations in check.  If you forget about that it's not so bad.  Look fast for a young Marla Gibbs as a bartender.1974HOT POTATOKelly plays Jones (though, to the best of my knowledge, not Black Belt Jones), who coordinates the rescue of a Senator's daughter (Judith Brown, "House Calls"), kidnapped in Thailand by Rangoon (Sam Hiona, "An Eye For An Eye").  Rangoon hires a look-alike (Brown again) to "allow" the rescue to take place.  Helping Jones out are his buddy, Johnny Chicago (Geoffrey Binney, "Kung Fu Cannibals"), Detective Pam Varaje (Irene Tsu, "The Green Berets") and the corpulent clown known as White Rhino (George Memmoli, "Rocky"), who distracts enemies with a stupid remote-control police car.This is easily the worst film in this set and should probably be avoided. It really makes me wish Warner Bros would've thrown in "The Tattoo Connection" instead.  The fights pretty much suck but there are some nice sets and location use.  Rangoon's compound was clearly influenced by Han's lair in "Enter the Dragon". There is a sense of fun and to those that appreciate bad movies for the sake of bad movies there's perhaps some value.  Otherwise it's pretty stinky. 1.5/51976BLACK SAMSONRockne Tarkington ("Wyatt Earp") plays the title role, the owner of a neighborhood bar and a lion.  He helps keep his community drug-free by carrying a big stick and he is locally liked and respected.  Everything is groovy until mobster Johnny Nappa (the excellent William Smith, "Maniac Cop") tries to muscle in on his territory.  Nappa's boss tells him to go easy on Samson but Nappa feels he's been dissed and totally has it out for the guy.  When Johnny's girlfriend (the cute, topless Connie Strickland) fails to earn Samson's trust, Johnny kidnaps Samson's girlfriend Tina (the even cuter Carol Speed, "The Mack").So I buy a 4-pack to get 3 Jim Kelly movies and the best one is the only one that doesn't star him.  I liked this movie quite a bit.  This is far from an award-winning plot but it's handled competently.  Samson's easy to root for and the bad guy is a vicious jerk.  The only real disappointment is that there's no martial arts but there are a handful of decent, tough fights.  3.5/51974.  aka: SamsonTHREE THE HARD WAYWe start with a young black man escaping some sort of compound. He's injured but finds his way to his friend, music producer Jimmy Lait (NFL hall-of-famer Jim Brown, "Mars Attacks"), but passes out before telling him what happened.  Jimmy takes him to a hospital but bails to finish his recording session with The Impressions (appearing as themselves and performing the title song) and leaves his girlfriend, Wendy (Sheila Frazier, "Superfly"), to look after him.  Thugs track the dude down and finish him off, capturing Wendy in the process.  Jimmy calls his buddies, Jagger Daniels (Fred Williamson, "From Dusk Till Dawn") and Mister Keyes (Kelly) to help him out.  Within seconds of getting together they're at a random car wash to look for clues and are shot at.  They manage to capture a dude and Daniels knows of a topless trio of babes (known as the countess, the empress and the princess) to torture information out of the sad sack.  Turns out that these jerks have developed a serum to enter into the water supply of Washington, L.A. and Detroit that's harmless to whites but will kill all the blacks!  3 cities, 3 of them, 3 the hard way!Directed by Gordon Parks, Jr. ("Superfly") and featuring prolific stunt coordinator Hal Needham and his team, this is a really fun film if one can firmly remove the logic filter from one's brain.  Tons of shoot outs, quite a few fights and cars that explode seemingly at random.  Man, they blow up a lot of cars.  This is as dumb as they come but done about as well as it could be for the time and I can't think of 3 dudes to star who would've been better.  Frankly, I liked it a lot.  3.5/51974While hardly a Blaxploitation aficionado I have liked most of them that I've seen and, as of this writing, the price justifies purchase if this is your cup of tea.  None of these films are great but, depending on your opinion and tolerance of silliness, none of them are bad either.  Except "Hot Potato".
summary: "Necessity, besides being the mother of invention, can also be the wife of deception."

reviewText: 3 great films and one to fast forward through. Black Belt Jones is a hilarious martial arts flick. Jim Kelly's physicalities make up for what he lacks as an actor. Kelly jap slaps people faster than most, has the coolest mushroom afro, wears decent 70's threads, and has a cro-magnon ripped physique! Government agent Jones helps an inner city karate school fight off mafia hoods from taking the property over. Kelly's lightning fast moves keeps the fight scenes exciting no matter how goofy the movie ends up. Gloria Hendry is a hellcat with a presence when fighting with a nice shapely rump behind her. The opening theme pales in comparison to the rest of the well made, inventive score. No special features. Hot Potato is the unfunny sequel with Jim Kelly not even able to travel through a doorway with his even bigger afro and who knows what lurks in it. Jones goes to Thailand and with three other agents, rescues a kidnapped woman from a bunch of guys wearing head bands and pajamas. The ending is the only decent fight scene as jones's gang takes on a whole town of unemployed snake charmers loyal to a fu manchu lookalike. No extras. Kelly returns with Jim Brown and Fred Williamson in 3 the hard way. White supremacists try to poison the water with a chemical that only effects black people. Its the magnificent three as kelly slaps, Brown and Williamson shoot, and reverse genocide commences. Whitey, dressed in glorified cub scout uniforms, are out-fought, out-shot, out-thought, and are practically rounded up like cattle and run off a cliff. During the slaughter, we get some great action scenes and believe it or not Fred Williamson isn't bad in this. No emotion required from the leads, so with the same amount of ammo used in both WW1 and 2, they decimate whitey's nazi brigade and that's how it ends. The film score complements all the action. Well filmed, with some decent slo-mo in Kelly's introductory fight with fake cops. No extras. Rockne Tarkington? is black Samson, a bar owner who has probably never been to Africa but looks like he has-wearing cultural duds and carrying a big stick. Samson fights the mob as they try to take over his neighborhood. William Smith as the mob boss's right hand man, goes on "roid rage" throwing his girlfriend out of a moving car, breaking a bottle over a guy's head, manhandling Samson's woman, and uses the "n" word with a total disregard for political correctness. Samson totally out-fights, out-thinks, and practically rounds up whitey like cattle and runs him off a cliff. The action is plentiful and well choreographed with the sound effects giving us that knarly slap we love to hear. Black Samson delivers the action and William Smith, who tears up his scenes with a brilliant evil performance you will love to hate. No extras. 16x9 dvd picture and sound on all four movies has been well done.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thankfully none of these films star Keith Urban, but are instead some previously unavailable Blaxploitation films.  Coz as we all know now, "Urban" means "Black".  I found this out years ago working at a video store when reading the monthly business catalogues that advertised "urban" films like Phat Beach and Belly as being very profitable in "urban neighborhoods".But anyhow, there are fewer Blaxploitation fans as big as I(in loyalty, not body mass), and I've been waiting to get my mitts on two of these titles for some time now.  Three of the four films feature martial artist, Jim Kelly, who we all remember from Enter the Dragon as John Saxon's buddy.  First on the bill is Black Belt Jones, directed by Enter the Dragon's director, Robert Clouse.  Jones is an all around butt kicker who works for a karate school run by Scatman "How'd you like some ice cream, Doc?" Crothers.  He's also working with the feds or something.  Some mafiosos employ their "urban" man, Pinky, to try and gain possession of the karate school by any means possible to expand their evil real estate project.  Well, after Pinky's goons start roughing up Jones' pals, it's all out war with Jones slapping the snot out of everyone and winning over Gloria Hendry(who does some snot slapping herself).  Tongue in cheek, and as Ronnie Dawson would say, "ACTION PACKED!"Next up is Hot Potato, and this is the odd film out of the four.  A sort of semi-sequel to Black Belt Jones, it's directed by the writer of that film......and it's rather lousy.  Kelly is an agent names Jones(which is why we can assume this is some sort of sequel) in Thailand on a mission to rescue a senator's daughter or something(I ceased to care about plot details rather early on here) from an evil Thai crime lord guy.  He gangs up with his white partner and an obese comic relief brawler(who has sandwiches fall from his shirt every time he removes it) to carry out the mission.  This film is lots and lots of stumbling around in the jungle and getting into little adventures and fights along the way.  It's done as flat out zany comedy, but it's extremely unfunny and boring.  Definitely the least "Urban" of the four films.  Best left in the vaults.Things look up in Black Samson.  Samson's one tough dude who runs a bar, carries a staff and owns a lion.  He runs the neighborhood and tries to keep it drug and crime free.  Once again the crime syndicate is after the property coz it's an essential piece to their plan.  All around tough and evil looking villain, William Smith is given the task of breaking Samson down.  But we all know what happens to evil white folks, especially William Smith, in these kinds of films.  Good film that benefits from some good performances, especially the two leads.Finally it's Three The Hard Way, with a great "urban" cast of Jim Kelly, Fred Williamson and Jim Brown.  It's dircted by Gordon Parks, jr, who did Superfly.  A white supremacist whack job plans on wiping out the "urban" race by poisoning the water supply, and it's up to three bad dudes to put a stop to it.  Oddly enough, considering the cast and the director, this film is kind of a letdown.  It's not bad, but certainly not as fun as it could have been.  It's a lot better than Hot Potato, I'll tell you that.  Three The Hard Way has been available, but in very lousy public domain versions, like many of Williamson's films.  It's nice to see it get a proper release.Considering the price, this package isn't bad at all.  Two good films, one decent and one forgettable isn't bad for the low asking price.  And the films are on two one-sided discs, which is very welcome.  The quality is good.  it's not painstakingly remastered or anything, but very acceptable.  Worth it if you like the Blaxploitation genre, for sure.
Title: N/A

reviewText: (Black Belt Jones)The Mob want to buy a local karate studio in a city area planned for re-development. They enlist the aide of a local thug named "Pinky" and his henchmen to force the owner into selling. After they accidentally kill him, the karate students call on their number one kung-fu expert "Black Belt Jones" to even the score.(Hot Potato)A really weak sequel to 1974's "Black Belt" Jones. Jim Kelly reprises his role as a US government agent named Jones. This time around Jones travels to Thailand to rescue the daughter of a southern U.S. senator, who is being held by a ruthless crime lord named Rangoon.(Black Samson)These streets belong to Samson!  A local nightclub owner Samson does everything he can to keep his neighborhood clean of crime, corruption and drugs. When a local mobster named Johnny Nappa played by William Smith tries to take over Samson's turf, Samson the staff wielding hero takes a stand against Nappa and his hoods to save his girl and the neighborhood.(Three the Hard Way)A white supremist named Monroe Feather plots to taint the United States water supply in several US cities with a toxin that is harmless to white people but lethal to black people. Standing in Monroe Feathers way are Jimmy Lait, Jagger Daniels and Mister Keyes, who'll stop at nothing to bring down Monroe Feathers and his supremist organization for good.Whether you're a fan of Jim Brown, Jim Kelly, Fred "The Hammer" Williamson or Blaxploitation films in general; the Urban Action Collection has something for everyone. The 1970's gave rise to the Blaxploitation film genre and thanks to Warner Home Video we can now enjoy some of these classic films through the first legitimate DVD release from a major studio like Warner Home Video.Fans of "Black Belt Jones" and "Three the Hard Way" can finally throw away those crappy bootlegs because the film prints used by Warner Home Video in this collection are outstanding to say the least. Either the prints were in excellent condition to begin with or Warner Bros spent some money to clean them up, because I've never seen these films look and sound so good.The Urban Action Collection consists of 4 films on two single sided discs, that's right no double sided discs to fumble with. You get two movies per disc and all four films are in their 1.85:1 widescreen aspect ratio and the picture and sound quality are excellent. Fans of these films will rejoice in what they see and hear the moment they press the play button on their remote.I expected these films would be riddled with tons of grain and plagued with sound problems, but that definitely wasn't the case. The prints used are fantastic, the picture is sharp and the colors are really vibrant. These films looked and sounded great on my 50" Panasonic Plasma, the only thing I would have changed would be the sound options. Three of the four films should have been in 5.1 Digital Dolby or at least stereo given their funky soundtracks.
summary: ONE POTATO... TWO POTATO... HOT POTATO?
